reviewText: Mike Henry's final appearance as Tarzan, "Tarzan and the Jungle Boy" (filmed in Brazil in 1966, but released in 1968), was, by all accounts, a very difficult production; after "Tarzan and the Great River", when the actor was hospitalized for weeks after being badly bitten on the chin by his chimp (forcing the monkey to be put down), Henry was exhausted, and announced "Jungle Boy" would be his final 'Tarzan' appearance (Ron Ely would replace him in the television series). He asked for time off between films to rest and recuperate, which producer Sy Weintraub agreed to; however, with rainy season approaching, and television work awaiting the completion of the final film, Henry's request had to be set aside, and the mounting pressures of the short deadlines created a whole new series of problems; Henry's dysentery, contracted during "Great River", flared up, again, and a long fall resulted in a very painful ear infection, which then developed into a viral infection of his liver. Meanwhile, the rains began early, resulting in the worst floods in Rio in nearly 100 years, dragging out the production even longer. Filming became a nightmare which wouldn't end!The first Henry film 'set' in Africa (although filmed entirely in Brazil), stock African footage was used extensively to create the 'Dark Continent' illusion. There were two intertwining plotlines; the first involved a boy (Steve Bond, who later became a popular star on television's "General Hospital), lost for years in the jungle, whose discovery becomes the obsession of a reporter ("From Russia with Love's" sexy Aliza Gur). The boy is located in the 'forbidden' jungle of a hostile tribe, which introduces the second storyline; with the impending death of the chief, his two sons, portrayed by Olympian Rafer Johnson (in his second 'Tarzan' appearance), and, I suspect, his real-life brother, Edward (no background info is offered), compete for the right to assume the crown. When Tarzan reveals Rafer is attempting to murder his brother during the contests, Edward is crowned, and the bitter Rafer plots the deaths of both his brother and Tarzan...Cheeta appears in the film, in footage shot before the monkey attacked Henry; it is more than a bit strange to see Aliza Gur nuzzling and kissing the chimp, knowing the animal's propensity towards violence! With the voluptuous, sensual Gur in the cast, you might assume that Tarzan might see some romance (the Ape Man hadn't even kissed a girl since Gordon Scott's tenure in the loincloth), but it never happens...Henry shows far more affection towards the jungle boy than he ever gives Gur!Considering the pain he was obviously enduring, Mike Henry does an extraordinary job, and still looked more like Tarzan than any actor, before or since. Sadly, by the time the film was released, he'd already left the role far behind. While he would do credible work in some well-remembered films (including John Wayne's "The Green Berets", and Burt Reynolds' "Smokey and the Bandit" series), stardom would elude Mike Henry, who never shared his experiences making the Tarzan films.The films, themselves, would remain his legacy!

reviewText: Mike Henry, as an Olympian, was a excellent choice for the lead actor in this movie.Of equal import, is the boy, Steve Bond, who was "Jukaro" the Jungle Boy.  In Africa,there were true stories of "Feral Children" who were lost but survived in the wilds.The boy actor, Steve Bond exhibited physical abilities and stamina which is a goodexample for other 12 year old boys to learn from and dream about adventures as a youthby natural abilities and talents not the fantasy world of video games and artificial electronics!This DVD is an excellent for family and individual viewing.  The entire DVD is a combinationof good landscaping and wildlife as well as the Natives in their environs whichprojected a superb presentation of a real Tarzan movie, not a phony setup.  Very welldone, and this was an excellent Heir Apparent for the Johnny Weissmuller Series.This is an outstanding movie worthy of a viewer's time and purchase!

reviewText: This 1968 90 minute color film stars Mike Henry in his third and last role as Tarzan.  A geologist, working in the jungle, leaves his worksite with his seven year old son and the boy's baby leopard in a canoe that is overturned in rapids. He is killed and the boy and leopard disappear. Six years later, people begin to believe that a wild boy living in the jungle with a leopard is the lost son. A female photographer asks Tarzan to help her find the boy and bring him back to civilization. Tarzan, she says, should understand the boy's situation because he went through the same kind of life. Tarzan's search is complicated by the rivalry of two brothers to be chief of the local tribe; one brother wants to kill his sibling and wants to murder the jungle boy as revenge against Tarzan for helping his brother. Tarzan's search is also complicated by the woman photographer who insists on joining Tarzan in his search for the jungle boy. Viewers may enjoy seeing if Tarzan is able to find the boy, what is he like, and will he be willing to leave the jungle and his animal friends. Mike Henry plays Tarzan well; the episodes with the two brothers are also good, but the story of the photographer and the boy are somewhat simplistic.
summary: Parts of the film are very good
Title: N/A

reviewText: If you like the old Johnny Weissmuller Tarzan movies you will probably like this one. Mike Henry's Tarzan character is a little better educated than the Tarzan played by the  more famous Johnny Weissmuller, but I believe that is in fact closer to the original character as written by Edgar Rice Burroughs. This movie does not have a "Jane" character, nor a "Boy" character (as in Tarzan's son), but it does have a boy (named Eric and played very well by Steve Bond) who has lived for years on his own in the jungle. This character is more like a young Tarzan or perhaps even more like a young Bomba (A part played by Johnny Sheffield in twelve movies after his run as Boy in Tarzan) than it is like the character Boy from the old Weissmuller movies.The movie does have a lot going on other than the interaction between Tarzan and Eric, in fact they do not meet until the late in the movie. The boy has been living in a part of the jungle where the local tribe does not allow outsiders (including Tarzan) to enter, but Tarzan feels he must enter anyway to find Eric. This is further complicated by a determined female reporter who will do anything to get her story.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Since I'm a great admirer of J/J, I found this film almost camp.  But I grew up with "Boy" back in the day and joined Tarzan through him in all his adventures.  This is a pleasant family film  Certainly easy paced and enjoyable, if one let's one imagination join in some most unrealistic scenarios.
summary: It's not your JImmy/Johnny's Tarzan and Boy!
